Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.
Additional staff from Biosciences and Chemistry will be involved in student supervision and will run tutorials - staff will vary depending on students numbers and projects chosen. External speakers will deliver the lecture content.

Overview

Overview
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. Students will also be taught the key skills required to undertake a research project (literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc). The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:
- Give students the necessary background and research skills to be able to undertake a biology or chemistry research project
- Prepare Students for employment and research beyond their MSc
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be split around preparing for the group project work which takes place in Semester 3 and supplemented with lectures and tutorials. Group work will be timetabled in order to ensure ample time spent on developing the area and roles for the research project. Outside speakers will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery. Students will be required to write a reflective blog throughout the year commenting on each of these speakers. The library staff will also provide a workshop and provide teaching on literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc to support students research and academic writing.

Students will also undertake project specific skills training. The 70 hours of skills training will take place in the supervisor’s research lab, including general labs with specialised equipment that will be used in the project, as well as access to a computer for data analysis and/or theoretical projects etc. Students will document their progress through this by submitting a portfolio at the end of the module. All project proposals will contain the following elements. Research, design, group work, evaluation and dissemination. Particular topics are allocated on an individual basis.
Teaching and Learning Methods
At the start of their MSc programme students will assess, in collaboration with their project group and supervisor, what skills they personally need to develop to be able to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then be given a series of research related activities to develop these necessary skills. Skills to be developed will include basic practical techniques; computing skills; additional background knowledge etc depending on the pathway/project chosen by the student. To help them develop both these skills and working as part of a team, group tutorials will be time tabled. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required levels of expertise. These practical activities will be complemented by a literature survey in the area of interest chosen by the group to provide the relevant background and to ensure that students can use their time constructively in their main research project. The exact nature of the module will vary depending on a student’s background and chosen research field. Students also will attend online Generic Research Skills lectures and workshops on Health & Safety, Information Retrieval, as well as optional lectures on employment.

Teaching method 1 - Lectures - delivered by industrial contacts to allow networking opportunities and enhance global citizenship and confidence.
Teaching method 2 - Tutorials - to plan group project work and for key research skills activities. This will include active learning and enhance confidence.
Teaching method 3 - skills acquisition. What this consists of will vary depending on the nature of the project chosen but will likely involve some practical work within the supervisors lab. This will involve active learning and building digital fluency through the computational and data handling aspects of the work.

All teaching methods above will be delivered in an inclusive manner (including group work considerations) and provide an excellent fit to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lectures will be delivered by external speakers and timetabled to potentially be accessible by other students within each department.

A typical teaching week will consist of 1 tutorial and ~4 hours of skills acquisition/practical work. With a lecture every 3-4 weeks.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through the following methods:

Literature Review for the final project (30%). Will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Draft essays will be submitted for formative feedback 2 weeks prior to the final deadline. The assessment will enhance digital fluency and confidence.

Group Project Plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group) - each student will develop an individual project plan based on their group plan. There will be a component which the group receives a mark for as whole and an individual mark (20%) . Will be distinct for each group/students and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Formative feedback will be given to students through the tutorials that will be used to plan group work. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship due to its collaborative nature.

Skills portfolio - documented evidence of how they have utilised their 70 hours. Blog summaries from external speakers. (40%) Skills portfolio will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship.

Generic Research Skills Assessment - based on key skills delivered in tutorials (10%). Anonymously assessed. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, and confidence through the acquisition of new skills.

Students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. All assessments are inclusive with considerations made for students who need special arrangements for group work or individual projects.

Late submission - standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy - there is a reassessment opportunity for all components. Alternative topics and an individual project plan will be provided when required. Industrial lectures will be recorded for blog resit opportunities. It will be capped at 50% and submitted in the normal reassessment window

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Acquire and apply appropriate experimental skills when undertaking work in a drug discovery research lab.
 LO2 Critically review, summarise and present relevant scientific literature when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
 LO3 Plan and justify an original research project in the field of drug discovery.
 LO4 Reflect on knowledge and skills acquired when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Students will have developed the skills to undertake a research project.- the ability to assimilate, evaluate and present research results objectively
 S2 Students will have improved competence in the planning and design of experiments- skills required to work independently and be self-critical in the evaluation of risks and experimental procedures and improved skills in the ability to select appropriate techniques and approaches.
 S3 Students will have developed the ability of self-direction; the ability to exercise initiative and personal responsibility and the ability for independent learning required for continuing professional development.
 S4 Students will have developed the personal attributes of research integrity and ethical practice

Notes

 S2 Students will have improved competence in the planning and design of experiments- skills required to work independently and be self-critical in the evaluation of risks and experimental procedures and improved skills in the ability to select appropriate techniques and approaches.
 S3 Students will have developed the ability of self-direction; the ability to exercise initiative and personal responsibility and the ability for independent learning required for continuing professional development.
 S4 Students will have developed the personal attributes of research integrity and ethical practice

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.
Additional staff from Biosciences and Chemistry will be involved in student supervision and will run tutorials - staff will vary depending on students numbers and projects chosen. External speakers will deliver the lecture content.

Overview

Overview
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. Students will also be taught the key skills required to undertake a research project (literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc). The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:
- Give students the necessary background and research skills to be able to undertake a biology or chemistry research project
- Prepare Students for employment and research beyond their MSc
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be split around preparing for the group project work which takes place in Semester 3 and supplemented with lectures and tutorials. Group work will be timetabled in order to ensure ample time spent on developing the area and roles for the research project. Outside speakers will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery. Students will be required to write a reflective blog throughout the year commenting on each of these speakers. The library staff will also provide a workshop and provide teaching on literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc to support students research and academic writing.

Students will also undertake project specific skills training. The 70 hours of skills training will take place in the supervisor’s research lab, including general labs with specialised equipment that will be used in the project, as well as access to a computer for data analysis and/or theoretical projects etc. Students will document their progress through this by submitting a portfolio at the end of the module. All project proposals will contain the following elements. Research, design, group work, evaluation and dissemination. Particular topics are allocated on an individual basis.
Teaching and Learning Methods
At the start of their MSc programme students will assess, in collaboration with their project group and supervisor, what skills they personally need to develop to be able to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then be given a series of research related activities to develop these necessary skills. Skills to be developed will include basic practical techniques; computing skills; additional background knowledge etc depending on the pathway/project chosen by the student. To help them develop both these skills and working as part of a team, group tutorials will be time tabled. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required levels of expertise. These practical activities will be complemented by a literature survey in the area of interest chosen by the group to provide the relevant background and to ensure that students can use their time constructively in their main research project. The exact nature of the module will vary depending on a student’s background and chosen research field. Students also will attend online Generic Research Skills lectures and workshops on Health & Safety, Information Retrieval, as well as optional lectures on employment.

Teaching method 1 - Lectures - delivered by industrial contacts to allow networking opportunities and enhance global citizenship and confidence.
Teaching method 2 - Tutorials - to plan group project work and for key research skills activities. This will include active learning and enhance confidence.
Teaching method 3 - skills acquisition. What this consists of will vary depending on the nature of the project chosen but will likely involve some practical work within the supervisors lab. This will involve active learning and building digital fluency through the computational and data handling aspects of the work.

All teaching methods above will be delivered in an inclusive manner (including group work considerations) and provide an excellent fit to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lectures will be delivered by external speakers and timetabled to potentially be accessible by other students within each department.

A typical teaching week will consist of 1 tutorial and ~4 hours of skills acquisition/practical work. With a lecture every 3-4 weeks.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through the following methods:

Literature Review for the final project (30%). Will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Draft essays will be submitted for formative feedback 2 weeks prior to the final deadline. The assessment will enhance digital fluency and confidence.

Group Project Plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group) - each student will develop an individual project plan based on their group plan. There will be a component which the group receives a mark for as whole and an individual mark (20%) . Will be distinct for each group/students and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Formative feedback will be given to students through the tutorials that will be used to plan group work. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship due to its collaborative nature.

Skills portfolio - documented evidence of how they have utilised their 70 hours. Blog summaries from external speakers. (40%) Skills portfolio will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship.

Generic Research Skills Assessment - based on key skills delivered in tutorials (10%). Anonymously assessed. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, and confidence through the acquisition of new skills.

Students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. All assessments are inclusive with considerations made for students who need special arrangements for group work or individual projects.

Late submission - standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy - there is a reassessment opportunity for all components. Alternative topics and an individual project plan will be provided when required. Industrial lectures will be recorded for blog resit opportunities. It will be capped at 50% and submitted in the normal reassessment window

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Acquire and apply appropriate experimental skills when undertaking work in a drug discovery research lab.
 LO2 Critically review, summarise and present relevant scientific literature when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
 LO3 Plan and justify an original research project in the field of drug discovery.
 LO4 Reflect on knowledge and skills acquired when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Students will have developed the skills to undertake a research project.- the ability to assimilate, evaluate and present research results objectively
 S2 Students will have improved competence in the planning and design of experiments- skills required to work independently and be self-critical in the evaluation of risks and experimental procedures and improved skills in the ability to select appropriate techniques and approaches.
 S3 Students will have developed the ability of self-direction; the ability to exercise initiative and personal responsibility and the ability for independent learning required for continuing professional development.
 S4 Students will have developed the personal attributes of research integrity and ethical practice

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.
Additional staff from Biosciences and Chemistry will be involved in student supervision and will run tutorials - staff will vary depending on students numbers and projects chosen. External speakers will deliver the lecture content.

Overview

Overview
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. Students will also be taught the key skills required to undertake a research project (literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc). The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:
- Give students the necessary background and research skills to be able to undertake a biology or chemistry research project
- Prepare Students for employment and research beyond their MSc
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be split around preparing for the group project work which takes place in Semester 3 and supplemented with lectures and tutorials. Group work will be timetabled in order to ensure ample time spent on developing the area and roles for the research project. Outside speakers will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery. Students will be required to write a reflective blog throughout the year commenting on each of these speakers. The library staff will also provide a workshop and provide teaching on literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc to support students research and academic writing.

Students will also undertake project specific skills training. The 70 hours of skills training will take place in the supervisor’s research lab, including general labs with specialised equipment that will be used in the project, as well as access to a computer for data analysis and/or theoretical projects etc. Students will document their progress through this by submitting a portfolio at the end of the module. All project proposals will contain the following elements. Research, design, group work, evaluation and dissemination. Particular topics are allocated on an individual basis.
Teaching and Learning Methods
At the start of their MSc programme students will assess, in collaboration with their project group and supervisor, what skills they personally need to develop to be able to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then be given a series of research related activities to develop these necessary skills. Skills to be developed will include basic practical techniques; computing skills; additional background knowledge etc depending on the pathway/project chosen by the student. To help them develop both these skills and working as part of a team, group tutorials will be time tabled. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required levels of expertise. These practical activities will be complemented by a literature survey in the area of interest chosen by the group to provide the relevant background and to ensure that students can use their time constructively in their main research project. The exact nature of the module will vary depending on a student’s background and chosen research field. Students also will attend online Generic Research Skills lectures and workshops on Health & Safety, Information Retrieval, as well as optional lectures on employment.

Teaching method 1 - Lectures - delivered by industrial contacts to allow networking opportunities and enhance global citizenship and confidence.
Teaching method 2 - Tutorials - to plan group project work and for key research skills activities. This will include active learning and enhance confidence.
Teaching method 3 - skills acquisition. What this consists of will vary depending on the nature of the project chosen but will likely involve some practical work within the supervisors lab. This will involve active learning and building digital fluency through the computational and data handling aspects of the work.

All teaching methods above will be delivered in an inclusive manner (including group work considerations) and provide an excellent fit to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lectures will be delivered by external speakers and timetabled to potentially be accessible by other students within each department.

A typical teaching week will consist of 1 tutorial and ~4 hours of skills acquisition/practical work. With a lecture every 3-4 weeks.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through the following methods:

Literature Review for the final project (30%). Will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Draft essays will be submitted for formative feedback 2 weeks prior to the final deadline. The assessment will enhance digital fluency and confidence.

Group Project Plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group) - each student will develop an individual project plan based on their group plan. There will be a component which the group receives a mark for as whole and an individual mark (20%) . Will be distinct for each group/students and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Formative feedback will be given to students through the tutorials that will be used to plan group work. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship due to its collaborative nature.

Skills portfolio - documented evidence of how they have utilised their 70 hours. Blog summaries from external speakers. (40%) Skills portfolio will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship.

Generic Research Skills Assessment - based on key skills delivered in tutorials (10%). Anonymously assessed. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, and confidence through the acquisition of new skills.

Students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. All assessments are inclusive with considerations made for students who need special arrangements for group work or individual projects.

Late submission - standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy - there is a reassessment opportunity for all components. Alternative topics and an individual project plan will be provided when required. Industrial lectures will be recorded for blog resit opportunities. It will be capped at 50% and submitted in the normal reassessment window

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Acquire and apply appropriate experimental skills when undertaking work in a drug discovery research lab.
 LO2 Critically review, summarise and present relevant scientific literature when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
 LO3 Plan and justify an original research project in the field of drug discovery.
 LO4 Reflect on knowledge and skills acquired when undertaking research in the field of drug discovery.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Students will have developed the skills to undertake a research project.- the ability to assimilate, evaluate and present research results objectively
 S2 Students will have improved competence in the planning and design of experiments- skills required to work independently and be self-critical in the evaluation of risks and experimental procedures and improved skills in the ability to select appropriate techniques and approaches.
 S3 Students will have developed the ability of self-direction; the ability to exercise initiative and personal responsibility and the ability for independent learning required for continuing professional development.
 S4 Students will have developed the personal attributes of research integrity and ethical practice

Lectures will be delivered by external speakers and timetabled to potentially be accessible by other students within each department.

A typical teaching week will consist of 1 tutorial and ~4 hours of skills acquisition/practical work. With a lecture every 3-4 weeks.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through the following methods:

Literature Review for the final project (30%). Will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Draft essays will be submitted for formative feedback 2 weeks prior to the final deadline. The assessment will enhance digital fluency and confidence.

Group Project Plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group) - each student will develop an individual project plan based on their group plan. There will be a component which the group receives a mark for as whole and an individual mark (20%) . Will be distinct for each group/students and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Formative feedback will be given to students through the tutorials that will be used to plan group work. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship due to its collaborative nature.

Skills portfolio - documented evidence of how they have utilised their 70 hours. Blog summaries from external speakers. (40%) Skills portfolio will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship.

Generic Research Skills Assessment - based on key skills delivered in tutorials (10%). Anonymously assessed. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, and confidence through the acquisition of new skills.

Students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. All assessments are inclusive with considerations made for students who need special arrangements for group work or individual projects.

Late submission - standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy - there is a reassessment opportunity for all components. Alternative topics and an individual project plan will be provided when required. Industrial lectures will be recorded for blog resit opportunities. It will be capped at 50% and submitted in the normal reassessment window

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 S3 Students will have developed the ability of self-direction; the ability to exercise initiative and personal responsibility and the ability for independent learning required for continuing professional development.
 S4 Students will have developed the personal attributes of research integrity and ethical practice

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.
Additional staff from Biosciences and Chemistry will be involved in student supervision and will run tutorials - staff will vary depending on students numbers and projects chosen. External speakers will deliver the lecture content.

Overview

Overview
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. Students will also be taught the key skills required to undertake a research project (literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc). The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to:
- Give students the necessary background and research skills to be able to undertake a biology or chemistry research project
- Prepare Students for employment and research beyond their MSc
Marketing Module Synopsis
The Introduction to research module aims to familiarise students with the fundamental concepts, methodologies, and practices involved in conducting research and prepare them for employment/research beyond their MSc. Students will define and plan their group research project, conduct a literature review in order to fully understand the research they will undertake in their final research project. The module will also involve exposure to speakers who will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery.
The module will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and lab skills. Students will be assessed through a literature review , group project plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group), skills portfolio, generic research skills activities and blog summaries from external speakers.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be split around preparing for the group project work which takes place in Semester 3 and supplemented with lectures and tutorials. Group work will be timetabled in order to ensure ample time spent on developing the area and roles for the research project. Outside speakers will be invited from industry, funders, investors, and regulatory bodies to talk about every aspect of drug discovery. Students will be required to write a reflective blog throughout the year commenting on each of these speakers. The library staff will also provide a workshop and provide teaching on literature searching, referencing, EndNote, copyright, evaluation of information sources etc to support students research and academic writing.

Students will also undertake project specific skills training. The 70 hours of skills training will take place in the supervisor’s research lab, including general labs with specialised equipment that will be used in the project, as well as access to a computer for data analysis and/or theoretical projects etc. Students will document their progress through this by submitting a portfolio at the end of the module. All project proposals will contain the following elements. Research, design, group work, evaluation and dissemination. Particular topics are allocated on an individual basis.
Teaching and Learning Methods
At the start of their MSc programme students will assess, in collaboration with their project group and supervisor, what skills they personally need to develop to be able to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then be given a series of research related activities to develop these necessary skills. Skills to be developed will include basic practical techniques; computing skills; additional background knowledge etc depending on the pathway/project chosen by the student. To help them develop both these skills and working as part of a team, group tutorials will be time tabled. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required levels of expertise. These practical activities will be complemented by a literature survey in the area of interest chosen by the group to provide the relevant background and to ensure that students can use their time constructively in their main research project. The exact nature of the module will vary depending on a student’s background and chosen research field. Students also will attend online Generic Research Skills lectures and workshops on Health & Safety, Information Retrieval, as well as optional lectures on employment.

Teaching method 1 - Lectures - delivered by industrial contacts to allow networking opportunities and enhance global citizenship and confidence.
Teaching method 2 - Tutorials - to plan group project work and for key research skills activities. This will include active learning and enhance confidence.
Teaching method 3 - skills acquisition. What this consists of will vary depending on the nature of the project chosen but will likely involve some practical work within the supervisors lab. This will involve active learning and building digital fluency through the computational and data handling aspects of the work.

All teaching methods above will be delivered in an inclusive manner (including group work considerations) and provide an excellent fit to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lectures will be delivered by external speakers and timetabled to potentially be accessible by other students within each department.

A typical teaching week will consist of 1 tutorial and ~4 hours of skills acquisition/practical work. With a lecture every 3-4 weeks.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed through the following methods:

Literature Review for the final project (30%). Will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Draft essays will be submitted for formative feedback 2 weeks prior to the final deadline. The assessment will enhance digital fluency and confidence.

Group Project Plan (GANNT, roles, subjects, skills defined by group) - each student will develop an individual project plan based on their group plan. There will be a component which the group receives a mark for as whole and an individual mark (20%) . Will be distinct for each group/students and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. Formative feedback will be given to students through the tutorials that will be used to plan group work. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship due to its collaborative nature.

Skills portfolio - documented evidence of how they have utilised their 70 hours. Blog summaries from external speakers. (40%) Skills portfolio will be distinct for each student and supervisors will contribute to marking so anonymous assessment is not possible. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, confidence and global citizenship.

Generic Research Skills Assessment - based on key skills delivered in tutorials (10%). Anonymously assessed. The assessment will enhance digital fluency, and confidence through the acquisition of new skills.

Students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. All assessments are inclusive with considerations made for students who need special arrangements for group work or individual projects.

Late submission - standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy - there is a reassessment opportunity for all components. Alternative topics and an individual project plan will be provided when required. Industrial lectures will be recorded for blog resit opportunities. It will be capped at 50% and submitted in the normal reassessment window

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
